verse: Time passed, and David’s children grew older. David’s third son, Absalom, had a sister, Tamar, who was so beautiful that David’s oldest son and heir, Amnon, fell in love with her.
Amnon was actually sick with desire for his half sister Tamar. Because she was a royal virgin, there was no chance for him to be with her.
But Amnon had a friend, his cousin Jonadab (son of David’s brother Shimeah), who was very shrewd.
So Amnon did as Jonadab had suggested. He lay down and faked an illness, and the king came to check on him, just as Jonadab said he would.
David sent word home to Tamar.
Tamar came to Amnon’s house, where he waited in bed. She made dough, kneaded it, formed cakes, and baked them, all so that he could watch her.
Then she set the pan in front of him and served the food, but he would not eat.
But Amnon would not listen to her; and since he was stronger, he raped her.
After he was done, he was filled with disgust and hated her; his hatred was stronger than the love that motivated him to rape her.
He called for his manservant.
Because Tamar had been a royal virgin, she wore a distinctive robe with long sleeves. When Amnon’s servant threw her out into the street and barred her return,

Tamar heaped ashes on her head and tore her long, beautiful robe in mourning for what had happened to her. Then she walked back toward her home wailing, one hand to her head, showing everyone that tragedy and shame had fallen on her.
Tamar’s brother Absalom found her.
When King David heard of what Amnon had done, he was filled with anger, but he did nothing to punish his firstborn son.
For his part, Absalom would not talk to Amnon, either nicely or angrily; Absalom hated Amnon for raping his sister Tamar, but he waited patiently.
So two whole years passed. It was the time of year when Absalom’s sheep were to be sheared, and Absalom invited all the king’s sons to feast at his estate at Baal-hazor, near Ephraim.
He went to his father, the king, to ask for permission to invite his brothers.
But Absalom pushed and pressed him until finally David was persuaded to give his permission for Amnon and all of his sons to go.
But before it began, he gave his servants unusual instructions.
So Absalom’s servants followed his command and killed Amnon when he became drunk, and the other royal sons rose from the feast and fled on their mules.
While they were on the road, a false report reached David’s ears that all of his sons had been slain by Absalom, and no one had survived.
The king tore his clothes and fell to the ground in mourning. All his servants who heard this news also tore their garments.
Then David’s nephew Jonadab (son of David’s brother Shimeah) told the king the truth.
Absalom fled.
When he had finished speaking, the sons of the king arrived. They shouted, they wept, and the king and all his servants joined them in bitter tears.

Absalom ran for his life. He sought sanctuary with his maternal grandfather, the king of Geshur (Talmai, son of Ammihud), and he stayed there for three years. Every day the king mourned for his lost son.
King David longed to pursue his son Absalom once he comforted himself concerning the death of his son Amnon.
